summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ OIG Special Agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons electronics technician at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The interview focuses on the technician's knowledge of the camera and recording systems in the MCC's Special Housing Unit (SHU) on August 9-10, 2019, the night of Jeffrey Epstein's death, and the technician's actions and observations on those dates.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the investigation. The interview is about the circumstances surrounding his death in the SHU on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: A correctional officer assigned to the SHU on the morning Epstein was found. The witness saw her there and described her as appearing disheveled and stressed.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A correctional officer in the SHU on the morning Epstein was found. The witness saw him picking Epstein up and helping move him to a stretcher.

persons.name: Warden Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: The warden of MCC at the time of the incident. The witness stated he provided phone logs to the warden after Epstein's death and spoke to him about the camera situation the next day.

connections.description: Both were correctional officers on duty in the SHU on the morning Jeffrey Epstein was found.

events.title: Camera System Failure Discovered
events.description: The electronics technician discovered that approximately 50-60 cameras, including most in the SHU, were not recording due to failed hard drives in an old system. He notified a supervisor but was told to go home and fix it the next day.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at MCC New York. A body alarm was activated, staff responded, performed CPR, and he was taken to medical. He was later pronounced dead.

events.title: FBI Investigation at MCC
events.description: The FBI arrived at MCC to investigate Epstein's death. They interviewed the electronics technician about the camera systems and took all the hard drives and recording equipment.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducted a sworn, recorded interview with the BOP electronics technician as part of its investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
Video Recording Room / SIS office, Third Floor, MCC
keyFacts: On August 9, 2019, the day before Epstein's death, the MCC's camera recording system failed. Approximately 50-60 cameras, including all but one camera in the SHU, were not recording due to old, failing hard drives.

The electronics technician discovered the failure around 1:00-2:00 PM on August 9th, verbally notified a supervisor, and was approved for overtime to fix it the next morning (August 10th). He states this was standard practice at the MCC, unlike at his previous institutions.

The only SHU camera recording on the night of August 9-10 was the "46-door" camera outside of 10 South. The footage was described as grainy. All other SHU cameras had a live feed but were not recording.

The witness responded to the body alarm on the morning of August 10th and assisted with chest compressions. He later returned to the SHU to help settle inmates, who were yelling at officers Noel and Thomas, claiming "you killed him" and "you didn't do rounds."

The witness believes Epstein's death was a suicide and a coincidence that it occurred when the cameras were down. He stated the system was old, failure was a known and recurring problem, and he saw no evidence of tampering.
